snippet: Defense lawyers for David Tarloff, who killed a woman in 2008, must meet a tough standard to prove insanity, even though he has received a diagnosis of schizophrenia.
abstract: Defense lawyers for David Tarloff, accused of murdering psychologist Kathryn Faughey on Upper East Side in 2008, will attempt tough insanity defense; Tarloff has been diagnosed with schizophrenia, but jurors must be convinced that he was so sick that he did not understand consequences of his actions at time of crime; standard is so difficult to meet that few defendants using insanity defense in New York win at trial.
lead_paragraph: Defense lawyers for David Tarloff, who killed a woman in 2008, must meet a tough standard to prove insanity, even though he has received a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

headline.seo: Mental Illness Is No Guarantee Insanity Defense Will Work for Tarloff
headline.main: Mentally Ill, but Insanity Plea Is Long Shot
headline.print_headline: Mental Illness Is No Guarantee Insanity Defense Will Work for Psychologist’s Killer
